repnme.cdata!:
India - Second Elementary Education Project
            (SSA II)

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Second Elementary
            Education Project for India were as follows: outcomes were
            moderately satisfactory, risk to development outcome was
            substantial, Bank performance was moderately satisfactory,
            and Borrower performance was moderately satisfactory. Some
            lessons learned include: strong political commitment and
            ownership are critical for successfully steering a centrally
            sponsored scheme. Sarva Shiksha Abhiyan (SSA) provided
            development partners (DPs) with a viable platform to provide
            consistent and concordant support to the program under a
            common results framework, jointly designed with the
            Government. A realistic assessment of the capacity is
            important to inform the design and sequencing of the reform
            programs for optimal impact. Regular diagnostic assessments
            for tracking student achievement are good initial steps
            towards improving student learning outcomes. Availability of
            timely and reliable data is essential for choosing the
            results indicators to measure the achievement of the
            development objectives. Communication is a key to successful interventions.

repnme.cdata!:
Striving for quality and universal
            elementary education through a flagship government program

abstracts.cdata!:
A flagship government education program
            in India, the largest of its kind in the world, has
            succeeded in bringing more than 17 million children to
            school that had previously been left outside the school
            system. The sarva shiksha abhiyan (SSA) program, backed by
            funds from the World Bank’s International Development
            Association (IDA), boosted the enrolment of children from
            poor families, marginalized, and tribal groups, and those
            with special needs. Around 54 percent of the children
            enrolled between 2003 and 2011 were girls. Now, the focus is
            on boosting the quality of education, as well as ensuring
            access for all. While the Bank’s financial support for SSA
            ends in 2012, the government will keep supporting SSA at
            least until 2017.

repnme.cdata!:
India - Additional Financing for Social
            Elementary Education Project

abstracts.cdata!:
This project paper provides an
            additional credit to the India Second Elementary Education
            Project. The additional credit will help finance the costs
            associated with additional and expanded activities to
            enhance the impact of a well-performing project for the
            Indian fiscal years of 2010-11 and 2011-12. It will also
            help to cover a financing gap in FY2009-10, as the initial
            International Development Association (IDA) credit which was
            designed to support FY2009-10 was fully disbursed in
            reimbursement of higher than expected FY2008-09
            expenditures. More specifically, the additional financing
            will enable expanded activities related increased access at
            upper primary level (grades 5-8), increased completion rates
            and improved learning outcomes for the full elementary cycle
            (grades 1-8), and enhanced ability to undertake national
            student learning achievement surveys in grades 3,5 and 8.
            The expected outcomes of these activities are a greater
            percentage of children attending and completing elementary
            education, and demonstrating satisfactory learning levels,
            across all socio-economic categories.

11889159.trustfund:
TF054642-EFA FTI EDUCATION PROGRAM
            DEVELOPMENT FUND-SOUTH ASIA REGION

abstracts.cdata!:
This Results Profile focuses on making
            elementary education universal in India. Despite
            unprecedented economic growth, India faces a big challenge
            in fighting poverty. Educational opportunities and access
            were uneven at best and marked by wide regional disparities.
            In 2000, around 39 million children under the age group of 6
            to 14 were not being schooled. In 2002, the International
            Development Association financed Elementary Education
            Project named Sarva Shiksha Abhiyan (SSA), to enroll all 6
            to 14-year-olds in school by 2010. Since 2001, the SSA has
            supported government efforts to bring 20 million
            out-of-school children into elementary education. It
            includes learners from long -deprived communities and
            minority communities, and children with special needs.
            Universal access was almost achieved, with more than 98
            percent of children having a primary school within one
            kilometer of home and many states almost approaching
            universal primary enrollment. A paradigm shift in teaching
            methods was pioneered in Tamil Nadu. In just two years, the
            activity-based learning method was scaled up across the
            schools. Several states were adapting the innovations.
